infodynamics.measures.continuous.kraskov

Class ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.continuous.ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
      • infodynamics.measures.continuous.kraskov.ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate, InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous, EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer, java.lang.Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov1, ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov2

    public abstract class ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov
extends ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
implements java.lang.Cloneable

    Computes the differential conditional mutual information of two multivariate double[][] sets of observations, conditioned on another (implementing ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate), using Kraskov-Stoegbauer-Grassberger (KSG) estimation (see references below). The implementation is made using fast-neighbour searches with an underlying k-d tree algorithm. This is an abstract class, building on the common code base in ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon, to gather common functionality between the two algorithms defined by Kraskov et al. Two child classes ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov1 and ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov2 then actually implement the two KSG algorithms.

    Crucially, the calculation is performed by examining neighbours in the full joint space (as specified by Frenzel and Pompe, and later by Vejmelka and Paluš, and Vlachos and Kugiumtzis) rather than two MI calculators.

    Usage is as per the paradigm outlined for ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate, with:

    • For constructors see the child classes.
    • Further properties are defined in setProperty(String, String).
    • Computed values are in nats, not bits!

    Finally, note that Cloneable is implemented allowing clone() to produce only an automatic shallow copy, which is fine for the statistical significance calculation it is intended for (none of the array data will be changed there).

    References:

    • Frenzel and Pompe, "Partial Mutual Information for Coupling Analysis of Multivariate Time Series", Physical Review Letters, 99, p. 204101+ (2007).
    • Vejmelka and Paluš, "Inferring the directionality of coupling with conditional mutual information", Physical Review E, 77, 026214, (2008)
    • I. Vlachos and D. Kugiumtzis, "Nonuniform state-space reconstruction and coupling detection", Physical Review E, 82, 016207, (2010)
    • Kraskov, A., Stoegbauer, H., Grassberger, P., "Estimating mutual information", Physical Review E 69, (2004) 066138.
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www), Ipek Özdemir

      • setProperty

        public void setProperty(java.lang.String propertyName,
               java.lang.String propertyValue)
        Sets properties for the KSG conditional MI calculator. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        Valid property names, and what their values should represent, include:

        • PROP_K -- number of k nearest neighbours to use in joint kernel space in the KSG algorithm (default is 4).
        • PROP_NORM_TYPE
          • -- normalization type to apply to working out the norms between the points in each marginal space. Options are defined by KdTree.setNormType(String) - default is EuclideanUtils.NORM_MAX_NORM_STRING.
        • #DYN_CORR_EXCL_TIME_NAME -- a dynamics exclusion time window, also known as Theiler window (see Kantz and Schreiber); default is 0 which means no dynamic exclusion window.
        • PROP_ADD_NOISE -- a standard deviation for an amount of random Gaussian noise to add to each variable, to avoid having neighbourhoods with artificially large counts. (We also accept "false" to indicate "0".) The amount is added in after any normalisation, so can be considered as a number of standard deviations of the data. (Recommended by Kraskov. MILCA uses 1e-8; but adds in a random amount of noise in [0,noiseLevel) ). Default 1e-8 to match the noise order in MILCA toolkit..
        • PROP_NUM_THREADS -- the integer number of parallel threads to use in the computation. Can be passed as a string "USE_ALL" to use all available processors on the machine. Default is "USE_ALL".
        • any valid properties for ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.setProperty(String, String), notably including ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.PROP_NORMALISE.

        Unknown property values are ignored.

        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Overrides:
        setProperty in class ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        propertyValue - value of the property
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for invalid property values

      • finaliseAddObservations

        public void finaliseAddObservations()
                             throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from class: ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
        Signal that the observations are now all added, PDFs can now be constructed. This default implementation simply puts all of the observations into the ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.var1Observations, ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.var2Observations and ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.condObservations arrays. Usually child implementations will override this, call this implementation to perform the common processing, then perform their own processing.
        Specified by:
        finaliseAddObservations in interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Overrides:
        finaliseAddObservations in class ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Allow child classes to throw an exception if there is an issue detected specific to that calculator.

                                         throws java.lang.Exception

      • computeAverageLocalOfObservations

        public double computeAverageLocalOfObservations(int variableToReorder,
                                       int[] reordering)
                                         throws java.lang.Exception

        As described in ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.computeAverageLocalOfObservations(int, int[])

        We provide a simple implementation which would be suitable for any child class, though the child class may prefer to make its own implementation to make class-specific optimisations. Child classes must implement Cloneable for this method to be callable for them, and indeed implement the clone() method in a way that protects their structure from alteration by surrogate data being supplied to it.

        If reordering is null, it is assumed there is no reordering of the given variable.
        Specified by:
        computeAverageLocalOfObservations in interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Overrides:
        computeAverageLocalOfObservations in class ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
        Parameters:
        variableToReorder - which variable to shuffle: 1 for variable 1, 2 for variable 2.
        reordering - permutation of the indices for the given variable; must be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the conditional MI under the new ordering, in nats (not bits!).
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                            throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate

        Computes the local values of the conditional mutual information, for each valid observation in the previously supplied observations (with PDFs computed using all of the previously supplied observation sets).

        If the samples were supplied via a single call such as ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.setObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]), then the return value is a single time-series of local channel measure values corresponding to these samples.

        Otherwise where disjoint time-series observations were supplied using several calls such as ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]) then the local values for each disjoint observation set will be appended here to create a single "time-series" return array.

        Specified by:
        computeLocalOfPreviousObservations in interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Returns:
        the "time-series" of local conditional MI values in either bits or nats depending on the estimator.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[][] states1,
                                             double[][] states2,
                                             double[][] condStates)
                                               throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Compute the local conditional MI values for each of the supplied samples in states1, states2 and condStates.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations, but not those in states1, states2 and condStates (unless they were some of the previously supplied samples).

        Specified by:
        computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations in interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        states1 - series of multivariate observations for variable 1 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        states2 - series of multivariate observations for variable 2 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number). Length must match states1, and their indices must correspond.
        condStates - series of multivariate observations for the conditional (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number). Length must match states1, and their indices must correspond.
        Returns:
        the series of local conditional MI values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeFromObservations

        protected double[] computeFromObservations(boolean returnLocals,
                               double[][][] newObservations)
                                    throws java.lang.Exception
        This protected method handles the multiple threads which computes either the average or local conditional MI (over parts of the total observations), computing the x, y and z distances between all tuples in time.

        The method returns:

        1. for (returnLocals == false), an array of size 1, containing the average conditional MI
        2. for local conditional MIs (returnLocals == true), the array of local conditional MI values
        Parameters:
        returnLocals - whether to return an array or local values, or else sums of these values
        newObservations - set to null for computing for the observation set for the PDF, or pass in a new set of observations to compute the average/locals for (using the existing observations to construct the PDF)
        Returns:
        either the average conditional MI, or array of local conditional MI value, in nats not bits
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • partialComputeFromObservations

        protected abstract double[] partialComputeFromObservations(int startTimePoint,
                                      int numTimePoints,
                                      boolean returnLocals)
                                                    throws java.lang.Exception
        Protected method to be used internally for threaded implementations. This method implements the guts of each Kraskov algorithm, computing the number of nearest neighbours in each dimension for a sub-set of the data points. It is intended to be called by one thread to work on that specific sub-set of the data.

        The method returns:

        1. for average conditional MIs (returnLocals == false), the relevant sums of digamma(n_{xz}), digamma(n_{yz}) and digamma(n_z) for a partial set of the observations
        2. for local conditional MIs (returnLocals == true), the array of local conditional MI values
        Parameters:
        startTimePoint - start time for the partial set we examine
        numTimePoints - number of time points (including startTimePoint to examine)
        returnLocals - whether to return an array or local values, or else sums of these values
        Returns:
        an array of the relevant sum of digamma(n_xz+1) and digamma(n_yz+1) and digamma(n_z), then sum of n_xz, n_yz, n_z and for algorithm 2 only, sum of 1/n_xz and 1/n_yz (these latter five are only for debugging purposes).
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • gpuComputeFromObservations

        protected double[] gpuComputeFromObservations(int startTimePoint,
                                  int numTimePoints,
                                  boolean returnLocals,
                                  int nb_surrogates,
                                  int[][] newOrderings,
                                  int variableToReorder)
                                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Protected method to be used internally for GPU implementations. This method serves the same purpose as partialComputeFromObservations, but for GPU computation. Each algorithm must override this method and implement a GPU routine to calculate all values in a single call to the GPU code.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int variableToReorder,
                                                   int numPermutationsToCheck)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Defined as per ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.computeSignificance(int) except that this method allows the user to specify which variable is shuffled (whilst the other has its relationship with the conditional preserved).
        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Overrides:
        computeSignificance in class ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
        Parameters:
        variableToReorder - which variable to shuffle: 1 for variable 1, 2 for variable 2.
        numPermutationsToCheck - number of surrogate samples to bootstrap to generate the distribution.
        Returns:
        the distribution of channel measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        #computeSignificance(int)}

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int variableToReorder,
                                                   int[][] newOrderings)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception

        As described in ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.computeSignificance(int, int[][])

        Here we provide a simple implementation which would be suitable for any child class, though the child class may prefer to make its own implementation to make class-specific optimisations. Child classes must implement Cloneable for this method to be callable for them, and indeed implement the clone() method in a way that protects their structure from alteration by surrogate data being supplied to it.

        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Overrides:
        computeSignificance in class ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
        Parameters:
        variableToReorder - which variable to shuffle: 1 for variable 1, 2 for variable 2.
        newOrderings - a specification of how to shuffle the values of the variable specified by variableToReorder to create the surrogates to generate the distribution with. The first index is the permutation number (i.e. newOrderings.length is the number of surrogate samples we use to bootstrap to generate the distribution here.) Each array newOrderings[i] should be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the distribution of channel measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - where the length of each permutation in newOrderings is not equal to the number N samples that were previously supplied.
        See Also:
        #computeSignificance(int[][])} except that this method all

      • partialComputeFromNewObservations

        protected abstract double[] partialComputeFromNewObservations(int startTimePoint,
                                         int numTimePoints,
                                         double[][] newVar1Observations,
                                         double[][] newVar2Observations,
                                         double[][] newCondObservations,
                                         boolean returnLocals)
                                                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Protected method to be used internally for threaded implementations. This method implements the guts of each Kraskov algorithm, computing the number of nearest neighbours in each dimension for a sub-set of the data points. It is intended to be called by one thread to work on that specific sub-set of the data. In particular, this method differs from partialComputeFromObservations(int, int, boolean) because it operates on a new set of observations (using the old set of observations for constructing the search spaces and PDFs)

        The method returns:

        1. for average conditional MIs (returnLocals == false), the relevant sums of digamma(n_{xz}), digamma(n_{yz}) and digamma(n_z) for a partial set of the observations
        2. for local conditional MIs (returnLocals == true), the array of local conditional MI values
        Parameters:
        startTimePoint - start time for the partial set we examine
        numTimePoints - number of time points (including startTimePoint to examine)
        newVar1Observations - new time series of observations for variable 1
        newVar2Observations - new time series of observations for variable 1
        newCondObservations - new time series of observations for variable 1
        returnLocals - whether to return an array or local values, or else sums of these values
        Returns:
        an array of the relevant sum of digamma(n_xz+1) and digamma(n_yz+1) and digamma(n_z), then sum of n_xz, n_yz, n_z and for algorithm 2 only, sum of 1/n_xz and 1/n_yz (these latter five are only for debugging purposes).
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
